Comment: I know what you are implying... but...  Javert is not a villain, although he does play the role of an antagonist. He is rigid and lawful and while he has a strong moral compass, his inflexibility is his weakness. Trump and MAGA has no moral compass, is not lawful and they flexible by turning on anyone or any issue.   Javert sees the world as black and white where lawbreakers are bad and must be punished, regardless of their reasons or personal transformation. Trump only sees black and white in those that oppose him. Lawbreakers are only bad if it doesn't serve him. Trump isn't interested in justice. He is only interested in himeself.  Javert doesn't see himself as the main character. He sees justice as the main character. Trump's entire goal is to make himself the main character in everyone else's life.  What makes Javert compelling is that he isn't cruel or evil. He is actually sincere, disciplined, and even admirable in his commitment. However, his inability to reconcile Jean Valjean's genuine reformation with his belief in absolute justice makes hime a tragic character. When faced with the mercy and moral complexity of Valjean's character, Javert experiences a crisis he cannot resolve.  Javert is not Trump or MAGA. Javert is not a traditional villain but is an antangonist. Javert is a tragic figure that that is destroyed by his own moral absolutism.  The Thenardier's on the other hand...

Comment: No. That would be banning them from their venue. Blacklisting is an industry-wide ban.  Edit: guys, blacklisting is an old term. It got popular during anti labor movements where bosses would fire you for attempting to unionize and they would tell other bosses so they wouldn't hire you.
Author: ItsSpaghettiLee2112

Comment: You're both somewhat correct, in a sense.   *You're* correct about the meaning of blacklisting and the fact that this is an attempt to create a blacklist whereby people on the list do not get work, similar to the Hollywood blacklist of the 40s and 50s.   The other user is correct in that this policy, in practice, would essentially be just a ban from the Kennedy Center, which they are already boycotting. Ric Grenell is not an industry bigwig and so he can create as many lists as he likes but they're less likely to be effective than if he was actually part of the industry.
Author: MarcusSurvives

Comment: There's direct language suggesting he wants to explicitly blacklist them and not simply ban them from the Kennedy Center.   >Ric Grenell, reacting Wednesday to headlines about cast members of Les Misérables who are planning to boycott President Donald Trump’s scheduled appearance next month, **demanded career-altering consequences** for “vapid and intolerant artists.”  ...  >“In fact, we think it would be important to out those vapid and intolerant artists **to ensure producers know who they shouldn’t hire** — and that the public knows which shows have political litmus tests to sit in the audience," he continued.
